data.profileText: a Representative from Connecticut; born in Hebron, Tolland County, Conn., October 20, 1755; pursued classical studies, and graduated from Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H., in 1775; studied law; admitted to the bar in November 1777 and commenced practice in Hebron; member of the Connecticut state house of representatives, 1780-1812; Connecticut state attorney for Tolland County, 1786-1807; chief judge of the county court and judge of the probate court, 1807-1818; principal of a law school, 1810-1818; member of the State senate in 1815 and 1816; elected as a Democratic Republican to the Fifteenth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Uriel Holmes and served from November 16, 1818, to March 3, 1819; resumed the practice of law in Hebron; again judge of the county court, 1820-1825; again a member of the Connecticut state house of representatives in 1826; died in Hebron, Conn., January 2, 1846; interment in Old Cemetery.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Uriel Holmes, and took his seat November 16, 1818.

researchRecord.name: 1846, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Sylvester Gilbert to Stuart Beebe written on March 18, 1846. In the letter, Gilbert answers some of Beebe's questions about the distribution and value of the estate of Sylvester Gilbert, father of his wife, Patience Langdon, and her sister Mrs. Beebe.

researchRecord.name: In the Little Family Papers, 1838-1997, 1 folder.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain 2 letters (1780, 1802), 1 document, and a biographical sketch of Sylvester Gilbert.
